Title: Best XC Shoe Ever
Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2020
Review: I'm a cross country runner just finishing senior year, I've been running for around 5 years and often go on 10 plus mile runs so I've had a lot of experience with different shoes. These shoes have a perfect balance of cushion, weight, and flexibility for me. Figure on a scale of 1-10 (1 being least and 10 being most)  they have like a 7 cushion, a 6 weight, and a 4 flexibility. I ran my senior season with these shoes and probably got around 400-450 miles into them and still there is like no wear, yeah most of the tread kinda got lost by like 250 miles but that's to be expected and they haven't fallen apart and still maintained most of the cushion. I'm buying this shoe again in a half size larger and will continue to do so for as long as my feet grow. The best long-distance running shoe I have ever used. Highly recommend if you're an XC runner, work perfectly for 3-15 mile run. I haven't run more than 15 miles so I don't know what happens after. Before using this shoe I ran with some Nikes which had no cushion, ended up getting knee and ankle injuries so I moved to this shoe, best choice ever!

Title: My Review After Putting 25 Miles On The UA Charged Assert Running Shoe
Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2020
Review:
For reference, I am 6'01 and 215 pounds and run 5 miles per day on pavement.  I typically jog and weight lift train while wearing some form of Asics running shoes, but decided to give these UA's a chance since I had been wearing a pair of UA's as my daily walking around shoe for over 6 months with zero issues.

I have now put 25 miles on these shoes so I feel I can give an honest and fair review.  I wear a size 12 shoe, bought a size 12 and they fit as expected.  It was described as a neutral shoe and it is.  The shoes matched exactly to the advertised picture.  The build quality appears to be very good and everything has held together nicely so far.  I also get decent air flow in the shoe while I am running.  I have run in both lighter and heavier shoes and I would put this UA in the medium weight column.

My only ISSUE is the left shoe heel, it is uncomfortable and annoying while jogging.  The included soles have a raised top on the heel area and apparently my left foot must be off ever so slightly while in the shoe.  My right foot is absolutely fine.  Perhaps I get some sort of defect?  I have decided to keep this shoes as my daily walking around shoes since I like the look of them, but am retiring the shoes from running.  I have already ordered Asics Gel-Excite 7 running shoes and will be posting a review on them in the near future.

Title: A Mess of Mesh
Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2019
Review:
These are the kind of shoes which feel great on your feet due to them giving the sensation of being part of your feet rather than on them. When I put them on at initially, I thought they were sized correctly in length but a bit narrow. However, after a few minutes, they seemed to conform to my feet and have remained there, for now, many miles.

There’s a curious feature which I see as a drawback. Much of the upper is a mesh. I can even see my toes through the shoe tops if the light is right. This means that almost any encounter with water will penetrate the shoe. I twice walked through shallow puddles and both times got my feet wet where with most shoes, this wouldn’t have happened given how shallow the water was.

I suppose this is supposed to make for a cooler shoe through venting but it doesn’t. In fact, these shoes feel hotter than any other low sneaker type shoe I have. Part of the problem may be my use of these shoes so far are in warm conditions from a low of 70F/21C to maybe 97F/36C. The mesh may be bringing in the hot ambient air into the shoe.

From a comfort view, these are top-notch. However, the mesh doesn’t seem to keep my feet cooler than a conventional sneaker shoe – just the opposite and any encounter with water will wet your feet inside the shoe.
